Project Management API

Postman collection OpenAPI spec

Introduction

The Project Management API allows you to create, update and delete projects and tasks, as well as add and manage comments. With authentication via Laravel Sanctum and properly documented endpoints, it provides a secure and well-organized solution for project management and collaboration.

Base URL: http://127.0.0.1:8000

This documentation aims to provide all the information you need to work with our API.

As you scroll, you'll see code examples for working with the API in different programming languages in the dark area to the right (or as part of the content on mobile). You can switch the language used with the tabs at the top right (or from the nav menu at the top left on mobile).

Initial configurations

For the API to work correctly, you must execute the following commands within the project:

  • composer install
  • php artisan migrate

They are necessary for the API to work

Authenticating requests

To authenticate requests, include an Authorization header with the value "Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}".

All authenticated endpoints are marked with a requires authentication badge in the documentation below.

You can recover your token by creating an account and logging into it.

Account Management

The Account Management encompasses endpoints dedicated to managing user profiles and profile pictures. It includes operations for viewing and updating profile information as well as managing the associated profile picture.

User Profile Retrieval.

GET
http://127.0.0.1:8000
/api/v1/user/profile
requires authentication

Retrieves detailed information from the authenticated user's profile, including personal data and profile picture.

Headers

Authorization
Example:
Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}
Content-Type
Example:
application/json
Accept
Example:
application/json
Auth
:
Bearer
Headers
:
:
Request failed with error

Tip: Check that you're properly connected to the network. If you're a maintainer of ths API, verify that your API is running and you've enabled CORS. You can check the Dev Tools console for debugging information.

Received response

Example request: 
curl --request GET \
    --get "http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/user/profile" \
    --header "Authorization: Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}" \
    --header "Content-Type: application/json" \
    --header "Accept: application/json"
const url = new URL(
    "http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/user/profile"
);

const headers = {
    "Authorization": "Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}",
    "Content-Type": "application/json",
    "Accept": "application/json",
};

fetch(url, {
    method: "GET",
    headers,
}).then(response => response.json());
$client = new \GuzzleHttp\Client();
$url = 'http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/user/profile';
$response = $client->get(
    $url,
    [
        'headers' => [
            'Authorization' => 'Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}',
            'Content-Type' => 'application/json',
            'Accept' => 'application/json',
        ],
    ]
);
$body = $response->getBody();
print_r(json_decode((string) $body));
import requests
import json

url = 'http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/user/profile'
headers = {
  'Authorization': 'Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}',
  'Content-Type': 'application/json',
  'Accept': 'application/json'
}

response = requests.request('GET', url, headers=headers)
response.json()
Example response:
{
    "user": {
        "id": 1,
        "name": "John Doe",
        "email": "john.doe@example.com",
        "created_at": "2024-08-24T13:50:23.000000Z",
        "updated_at": "2024-08-24T13:50:23.000000Z"
    },
    "profile_photo_url": "http://yourdomain.com/api/v1/user/profile-photo/get"
}
{
    "message": "Unauthenticated."
}

Update the user information

PUT
http://127.0.0.1:8000
/api/v1/user/update
requires authentication

Updates the authenticated user's profile information, allowing modifications to personal data

Headers

Authorization
Example:
Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}
Content-Type
Example:
application/json
Accept
Example:
application/json

Body Parameters

email
string

The new email of the user.

Example:
john.newemail@example.com
name
string

The new name of the user.

Example:
John Smith
Auth
:
Bearer
Headers
:
:
Body
{ "email": "john.newemail@example.com", "name": "John Smith" }
Request failed with error

Tip: Check that you're properly connected to the network. If you're a maintainer of ths API, verify that your API is running and you've enabled CORS. You can check the Dev Tools console for debugging information.

Received response

Example request: 
curl --request PUT \
    "http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/user/update" \
    --header "Authorization: Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}" \
    --header "Content-Type: application/json" \
    --header "Accept: application/json" \
    --data "{
    \"email\": \"john.newemail@example.com\",
    \"name\": \"John Smith\"
}"

const url = new URL(
    "http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/user/update"
);

const headers = {
    "Authorization": "Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}",
    "Content-Type": "application/json",
    "Accept": "application/json",
};

let body = {
    "email": "john.newemail@example.com",
    "name": "John Smith"
};

fetch(url, {
    method: "PUT",
    headers,
    body: JSON.stringify(body),
}).then(response => response.json());
$client = new \GuzzleHttp\Client();
$url = 'http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/user/update';
$response = $client->put(
    $url,
    [
        'headers' => [
            'Authorization' => 'Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}',
            'Content-Type' => 'application/json',
            'Accept' => 'application/json',
        ],
        'json' => [
            'email' => 'john.newemail@example.com',
            'name' => 'John Smith',
        ],
    ]
);
$body = $response->getBody();
print_r(json_decode((string) $body));
import requests
import json

url = 'http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/user/update'
payload = {
    "email": "john.newemail@example.com",
    "name": "John Smith"
}
headers = {
  'Authorization': 'Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}',
  'Content-Type': 'application/json',
  'Accept': 'application/json'
}

response = requests.request('PUT', url, headers=headers, json=payload)
response.json()
Example response:
{
    "id": 1,
    "name": "John Smith",
    "email": "john.newemail@example.com",
    "created_at": "2024-08-24T13:50:23.000000Z",
    "updated_at": "2024-08-24T13:50:23.000000Z"
}
{
    "message": "Unauthenticated."
}
{
    "message": "The name field is required. (and 1 more error)",
    "errors": {
        "name": [
            "The name field is required."
        ],
        "email": [
            "The email has already been taken."
        ]
    }
}

Update or Store Profile Picture.

PUT
POST
http://127.0.0.1:8000
/api/v1/user/profile-photo/store-or-update
requires authentication

Updates the authenticated user's profile picture or stores a new image if none exists.

Headers

Authorization
Example:
Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}
Content-Type
Example:
application/json
Accept
Example:
application/json

Body Parameters

base64
string
required

The base64-encoded image string.

Example:
data:image/png;base64,iVBORw...
Auth
:
Bearer
Headers
:
:
Body
{ "base64": "data:image\/png;base64,iVBORw..." }
Request failed with error

Tip: Check that you're properly connected to the network. If you're a maintainer of ths API, verify that your API is running and you've enabled CORS. You can check the Dev Tools console for debugging information.

Received response

Example request: 
curl --request PUT \
    "http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/user/profile-photo/store-or-update" \
    --header "Authorization: Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}" \
    --header "Content-Type: application/json" \
    --header "Accept: application/json" \
    --data "{
    \"base64\": \"data:image\\/png;base64,iVBORw...\"
}"

const url = new URL(
    "http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/user/profile-photo/store-or-update"
);

const headers = {
    "Authorization": "Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}",
    "Content-Type": "application/json",
    "Accept": "application/json",
};

let body = {
    "base64": "data:image\/png;base64,iVBORw..."
};

fetch(url, {
    method: "PUT",
    headers,
    body: JSON.stringify(body),
}).then(response => response.json());
$client = new \GuzzleHttp\Client();
$url = 'http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/user/profile-photo/store-or-update';
$response = $client->put(
    $url,
    [
        'headers' => [
            'Authorization' => 'Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}',
            'Content-Type' => 'application/json',
            'Accept' => 'application/json',
        ],
        'json' => [
            'base64' => 'data:image/png;base64,iVBORw...',
        ],
    ]
);
$body = $response->getBody();
print_r(json_decode((string) $body));

Create a comment for a project

POST
http://127.0.0.1:8000
/api/v1/projects/{project_id}/comments
requires authentication

Headers

Authorization
Example:
Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}
Content-Type
Example:
application/json
Accept
Example:
application/json

URL Parameters

project_id
string
required

The ID of the project.

Example:
dolorum

Body Parameters

content
string
required

The content of the comment, must be a minimum of 5 characters and a maximum of 1,500 characters.

Example:
nihil
Auth
:
Bearer
Headers
:
:
URL Parameters
:
Body
{ "content": "nihil" }
Request failed with error

Tip: Check that you're properly connected to the network. If you're a maintainer of ths API, verify that your API is running and you've enabled CORS. You can check the Dev Tools console for debugging information.

string
required

cumque

string
required

string
required

  • 'in-progress'

Tasks

The Tasks group includes endpoints designed for task management. It provides comprehensive functionality for handling tasks, covering all aspects from creation and viewing to updating and removal. This group offers a thorough approach to managing and maintaining tasks associated with the user.

Create Task.

POST
http://127.0.0.1:8000
/api/v1/projects/{project_id}/tasks
requires authentication

Creates a new task based on the provided information, adding it to the user's task set.

Headers

Authorization
Example:
Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}
Content-Type
Example:
application/json
Accept
Example:
application/json

URL Parameters

project_id
string
required

The ID of the project.

Example:
magnam

Body Parameters

title
string
required

The title of the project, must be at least 10 characters and a maximum of 150 characters.

Example:
consequatur
description
string
required

The description of the project, must be a minimum of 25 characters and a maximum of 1,500 characters.

Example:
Ex consectetur quo odit explicabo.
start_at
string
required

The start date of the project in Y-m-d (2024-12-31) and must be a date after or equal to today.

Example:
aut
end_at
string
required

The end date of the project in Y-m-d (2025-01-10) and must be a date after start at.

Example:
dolorem
status
string
required

The status of the project.

Must be one of:
  • 'available-soon'
  • 'in-progress'
  • 'done'
Example:
'in-progress'
priority
string
required

The priority of the project.

Must be one of:
  • 'low'
  • 'medium'
  • 'high'
Example:
'low'
assigned_email
string
required

The assigned_email of the project and there must be a user with that email

Example:
heaney.raphael@example.net

    \"title\": \"veritatis\",
    \"description\": \"Unde quaerat minus consectetur sequi.\",
    \"start_at\": \"perferendis\",
    \"end_at\": \"qui\",
    \"status\": \"\'available-soon\'\",
    \"priority\": \"\'low\'\",
    \"assigned_email\": \"rosamond.gerhold@example.com\"
}"

const url = new URL(
    "http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/projects/quis/tasks/quia"
);

const headers = {
    "Authorization": "Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}",
    "Content-Type": "application/json",
    "Accept": "application/json",
};

let body = {
    "title": "veritatis",
    "description": "Unde quaerat minus consectetur sequi.",
    "start_at": "perferendis",
    "end_at": "qui",
    "status": "'available-soon'",
    "priority": "'low'",
    "assigned_email": "rosamond.gerhold@example.com"
};

fetch(url, {
    method: "PUT",
    headers,
    body: JSON.stringify(body),
}).then(response => response.json());
$client = new \GuzzleHttp\Client();
$url = 'http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/projects/quis/tasks/quia';
$response = $client->put(
    $url,
    [
        'headers' => [
            'Authorization' => 'Bearer {YOUR_AUTH_KEY}',
            'Content-Type' => 'application/json',
            'Accept' => 'application/json',
        ],
        'json' => [
            'title' => 'veritatis',
            'description' => 'Unde quaerat minus consectetur sequi.',
            'start_at' => 'perferendis',
            'end_at' => 'qui',
            'status' => '\'available-soon\'',
            'priority' => '\'low\'',
            'assigned_email' => 'rosamond.gerhold@example.com',
        ],
    ]
);

User management

This API provides comprehensive authentication management capabilities, including user registration, login, and logout operations. Its endpoints allow for secure user authentication, issuance of access tokens, ensuring data protection and adherence to security best practices.

Create a user.

POST
http://127.0.0.1:8000
/api/auth/register

Headers

Content-Type
Example:
application/json
Accept
Example:
application/json

Body Parameters

name
string
required

The name of the user.

Example:
John Doe
email
string
required

The email of the user and this email must to be unique.

Example:
john.doe@example.com
password
string
required

The user's password. Must be at least 8 characters long, including letters, numbers, symbols, and at least one uppercase and one lowercase letter.

Example:
@123User
Headers
:
:
Body
{ "name": "John Doe", "email": "john.doe@example.com", "password": "@123User" }
Request failed with error

Tip: Check that you're properly connected to the network. If you're a maintainer of ths API, verify that your API is running and you've enabled CORS. You can check the Dev Tools console for debugging information.

Received response

Example request:

    "http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/auth/register" \
    --header "Content-Type: application/json" \
    --header "Accept: application/json" \
    --data "{
    \"name\": \"John Doe\",
    \"email\": \"john.doe@example.com\",
    \"password\": \"@123User\"
}"

Example:

required

Example:
"@123User"
